question.question-text: Why is the student talking to the professor?

answer-list.answer-text: To ask what will be on an exam
To review some material the professor covered in class
To turn in an exam paper

answer-text.exp: To find out why he did poorly on an exam

question.explain-text: In the conversation, the student says I'd like to ask you a question if I could and I didn't do very well on the last exam, the one on the structure of the Earth. From this, it can be determined that the student is talking to the professor to find out why he did poorly on an exam. The last answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: Indicate whether the ideas below are included in the conversation.

answer-list.answer-text:
The Earth's crust is thinner under land
than under the ocean.

The mantle makes up a large part of the
Earth's crust.
The Earth's core has three parts.

The Earth's inner core is liquid, and the
outer core is not.

explain-list.explain-text: The professor says here you said that the Earth's crust under landmasses is thin and the crust under the oceans is thick and that's not right; it's the opposite. This means that it is NOT true that the Earth's crust is thinner under land than under the ocean. You should therefore click in the NO column.

The professor says you said that the mantle is only a small part of the crust, but that's also not true. This means that it is true that the mantle makes up a large part of the Earth's crust. You should therefore click in the YES column.
The professor says there aren't three parts to the core; there are only two. This means that it is NOT true that the Earth's core has three parts. You should therefore click in the NO column.

The professor says look here, you got this wrong, too and you said that the inner core was liquid and the outer core was not. This means that it is NOT true that the Earth's inner core is liquid, and the outer core is not. You should therefore click in the NO column.

question.question-text: What does the professor mean when she says this:

answer-text.exp: "Perhaps your grade should have been lower."

answer-list.answer-text: "I don't think you deserve a score on this exam."
"I think you deserve a higher grade."
"It wasn't possible for you to do better."

question.explain-text: In the conversation, the professor says I think you can see why your grade was not very high and you'll need to do much better on the next exam. From this, it can be determined that when the professor says in fact, I'm not even sure you deserve the score you got, she means perhaps your grade should have been lower. The first answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: What does the professor mean when she says this:

answer-list.answer-text: "I'll tell you if I agree with you."
"I don't want to argue about it."

question.explain-text: In the conversation, the student says it would probably be quite difficult to do much worse, which means that he did really poorly on the exam, and the professor says you won't get an argument from me on that, which means that she is in absolute agreement with the student. The third answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: What conclusion can be drawn about how the student did on the exam?

answer-list.answer-text: He did not even know what the exam was about.
He got a lot of the information backwards.
He had most of the details correct.
He did a lot better on the exam than the professor thought.

question.explain-text: In the conversation, the professor says that's not right; it's the opposite and that's also not true and there aren't three parts to the core; there are only two, and look here, you got this wrong, too, and that's backwards, too. From this, it can be determined that the student got a lot of the information backwards on the exam. The second answer is therefore the best answer to this question.
